snippet: The man, accused by sign-language experts of being an impostor, said in interviews that he suffered from schizophrenia and had a tendency to violence.
abstract: Thamsanqa Jantjie, man accused of masquerading as a sign-language interpreter during Nelson Mandela's memorial service, tells interviewers that he is a violence-prone schizophrenic and had seen angels descending; assertions add one more bizarre turn to a story that has raised questions about the security at the ceremony.

byline.original: By NICHOLAS KULISH, JOHN ELIGON and ALAN COWELL
byline.contributor: Nicholas Kulish reported from Pretoria, John Eligon from Qunu, South Africa, and Alan Cowell from London.

lead_paragraph: The man, accused by sign-language experts of being an impostor, said in interviews that he suffered from schizophrenia and had a tendency to violence.

headline.main: Interpreter at Mandela Service Says He Is Schizophrenic and Saw Angels Descend
headline.print_headline: Interpreter at Memorial Service Says He Is Schizophrenic and Saw Angels Descend
